trial_identification.studytitle: Development of a mindfulness and compassion based program for young people: An intervention for sub-threshold and brief psychotic symptoms.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Development and evaluation of a mindfulness and compassion based program for young people with an at risk mental state: a randomized control trial.

interventions.interventions:
This Mindfulness with Compassion intervention is an 8-week group program with sessions delivered face to face for 1.5 hours once a week. The program will be delivered by two facilitators. The first facilitator has over 10 years experience working with youth with an ARMS. and has been a trained mindfulness teacher for the past 6 years. The second facilitator will may change from program to program. However, each co-facilitator will be a mental health professional who at a minimum will have sat an evidence-based mindfulness program as a participant and has a mindfulness practice. The program will be delivered in urban clinics.
The first half of the program introduces participants to mindfulness primarily through experiential exercises. It involves a variety of meditations and informal practices for use in daily life that are specifically tailored to the needs of the at risk mental state group. The fourth session takes a more didactic approach exploring the core difficulties associated with the at risk mental state and mapping these onto the three emotional regulation systems used in Compassion Focused Therapy. The remaining sessions continue to build participants mindfulness skills with an explicit focus on developing compassion.
interventions.comparator: Control group will be receiving treatment as usual (TAU). By TAU we mean the treatment participants would normally receive in the clinic they are attending regardless of the intervention study.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Self-Compassion assessed using the Self-Compassion Questionnaire by Neff (2003)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: There are three assessment points in this study; before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome:
Mindfulness
Assessed using the Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire by Baer et al. (2006)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Frequency of attenuated or brief psychotic symptoms assessed using the Comprehensive Assessment of the At Risk Mental Sate (CAARMS) by Yung et al. (2005).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Depression assessed using Depression Anxiety Stress Scale-21 (DASS-21) by Anthony et al. (2008)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Anxiety assessed using Depression Anxiety Stress Scale-21 (DASS-21) by Anthony et al. (2008)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Stress assessed using Depression Anxiety Stress Scale-21 (DASS-21) by Anthony et al. (2008)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Fear of Compassion as assessed using the Fear of Compassion Scale by Gilbert et al. (2011)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Self-Criticism and Reassurance assessed using Forms of Self-Criticizing/Attacking and Self-Reassuring Scale (FRCRS) by Gilbert et al. (2004)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Self-Connectedness assessed using Social Connectedness Scale by Lee and Robins (1995)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Social Functioning assessed using Global Functioning: Social and Role scales by Cornblatt et al. (2007)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Role Functioning assessed using the Global Functioning: Social and Role scales by Cornblatt et al. (2007)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Distress of attenuated or brief psychotic symptoms assessed using the Comprehensive Assessment of the At Risk Mental Sate (CAARMS) by Yung et al. (2005).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the intervention begins, when the intervention ends and 6 weeks later (i.e. pre-post and 6 weeks follow-up)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Meets criteria for the at risk mental state for psychosis as measured by the Comprehensive Assessment of At Risk Mental Statement (CAARMS)
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Currently acutely suicidal Organic brain syndrome Severe cognitive impairment Psychosis or schizophrenia Problematic substance abuse Insufficient fluency in English language

trial_design.concealment: Central randomization by an independent researcher using computer software
trial_design.sequence: An independent researcher will perform a randomized block allocation. Stratification will also be used based on (i) gender, (ii) life-time depression and (iii) duration of sub-threshold or brief psychotic symptoms.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: Descriptive statistics will be conducted and data will be examined to ensure that it meets the assumptions required for ANOVA tests. If all the assumptions are met, or solutions are found for assumptions that are not met, repeated measures ANOVA will be carried out. Significant overall effects will be followed-up with appropriate post-hoc tests.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of the study is to develop and pilot a mindfulness and compassion based group intervention for youth who meet the at risk for psychosis criteria. The program has been designed as an conjunct to treatment as usual. It specifically focuses on developing mindfulness and compassion skills in relation to attenuated psychotic symptoms, depression, anxiety, stress, self-criticism, social and daily functioning.
